# Arpeggio: 11th in G (Shape: E)

## Brief Presentation
This arpeggio is known as the 11th in G, even though it is played using the E shape on the guitar. It consists of the root note (G), major third (B), perfect fifth (D), major seventh (F#), and the eleventh note (C) of the G major scale. It is a versatile arpeggio that can add color and interest to chord progressions.

## Notes and Intervals
- Root (G)
- Major Third (B)
- Perfect Fifth (D)
- Major Seventh (F#)
- Eleventh (C)

## Musical Flavor and Usage
The 11th in G arpeggio has a rich and colorful sound due to the inclusion of the major seventh and eleventh notes. It can add a jazzy or sophisticated flavor to your music and works well in genres like jazz, fusion, and R&B. This arpeggio can be used to create interesting and complex chord progressions or as a melodic tool for improvisation.

## Songs
Here are three songs that use the 11th in G arpeggio:
1. "Spain" by Chick Corea - This jazz fusion classic features intricate chord progressions that could incorporate the 11th in G arpeggio.
2. "Cantaloupe Island" by Herbie Hancock - A jazz standard that could benefit from the color and flavor of the 11th in G arpeggio in improvisational sections.
3. "Neo Soul Jam" by D'Angelo - In R&B and neo-soul music, this arpeggio can be used to add depth and sophistication to chord voicings and melodies.
